Technical Specifications Required specifications (TOR Section 3.1) for a new borehole are 
listed below:
1) Final depth of the cased borehole will be at least 70m below ground 
level
2) All required supplies -casings, components, materials, and additional 
supplies- shall be new and first grade
3) The well casing shall extend above the ground about 60cm. The top 
end must have a sealed cap or wellhead box to prevent water 
ingress. For a steel casing, the exposed top section must be painted 
or coated to prevent corrosion
4) Angle of inclination from vertical will not to exceed 2.5 degrees at 
any point in the borehole
5)Casing must be completely round, with no ellipticity; the inner 
surface of casing must be smooth with no irregularities such as welds 
or couplings, which would reduce the inner diameter
6) The casing must be well cemented into the ground, from the bottom 
up
7) Steel casing with water-tight joints will be installed for the entire 
length of the borehole
8) Inner diameter of the casing should be between 12.7 and 17.8 cm (5 
and 7 inches) with a minimum casing wall thickness of 0.62 cm (0.244 
inches).
9) A water-tight cement or steel plug should be completely cemented 
to the bottom of the borehole.
10)The outer wall of casing should be completely cemented to the rock 
along the entire length of the borehole; cementation must ensure 
high-quality contact between the casing and the rock walls
11)The final cased borehole has to admit a test gauge, to be provided by 
the Contractor, of similar dimensions to the equipment to be 
installed at the borehole

 1. Summary of the project 
The 3 Component Auxiliary Seismic Station AS097 at Babate, Senegal (hereinafter referred to 
as “the Station”) is part of the International Monitoring System (IMS) of the Preparatory 
Commission for the Comprehensive Nuclear -Test-Ban Treaty Organization (hereinafter 
referred to as “the Commission”). More information can be found under www.ctbto.org  
The name, code and coordinates for the Station are  Babate, BBTS , 14.66132 ° N, 16.53323 ° W. 
The Station is at the site located approximately 75 km from the city of Mbour, Senegal.  The 
station is certified in 2007, to install the sensor inside the borehole, a  70m deep borehole was 
drilled in 2004; obstruction, verticality and leaking tests have been performed but later it’s been 
found that borehole had about 50m of water inside the casing. It was decided to drill another 
borehole which was drilled in 2006. After the drilling, a slight leaking was observed, but sensor 
was installed inside the borehole. Over the years, water and mud filled up the borehole and 
resulted corrosion on the casing. In 2023 the damaged sensor was pulled up and water was 
cleaned, however some water leakage was observed after the cleaning  as well . Summary of the 
report from the contractor is given in Section 7 in these TOR.  
The Commission considers rehabilitating the existing borehole (LOT 1) or drilling a new 
borehole (LOT 2)  and seeking a company specialized in these types of works . The Contractor 
can provide proposals on one or both lots.  
LOT 1:  Rehabilitating the existing borehole  include  (Section 2) ; 
- Cleaning the borehole  
- Cleaning and s ealing the casing  
- Cementing of the bottom of the Well  
- A pressure test after the cement dries to make sure no water entry to the Well  
 
LOT 2:  Drilling a new borehole (section 3);  
The new cased borehole  will be used to house a seismic instrument, which is a highly -
sensitive vibration -measuring device. The borehole needs to be nearly vertical and 
permanently sealed against water leakage from bottom to top. For this reason, the casing must be completely coupled over its entire length to the surrounding rock by careful 
cementation. A range of the inner diameter of the cased borehole is given to allow the 
Contractor to use the most cost -efficient drill bit available for drilling the borehole. This 
range also allows a variety of installations of seismic equipment in order to fit the site.  
Technical specifications of the borehole are given in section .1 3 in these TOR;  however,  
some important aspects of the borehole would be:  
- Corrosion -resistant stainless- steel casing  
- Steel casing is cemented into the borehole to stabilize the casing, provide good coupling to 
the ground, and maintain the integrity of underground aquifers. 
- A cement/bentonite -based grouting between borehole and the casing to seal the borehole to 
prevent any fluid movement, reinforce the hole against pressure.  
 
These Terms of Reference provide the technical description and requirements for the Work Tasks that shall be performed by the Contractor.

The borehole will be drilled using an appropriately sized drill bit for the final choice of casing

The vertical offset or drift for the deep borehole shall not exceed 2.5 degrees from true vertical measurement at any point from the top to the bottom of the cased hole.  It is suggested that this be achieved as follows: While drilling, pull -down pressure on the Kelly should be avoided. Drill 
pressure should be provided solely by the weight of the drill collars.  An appropriate device, such as a Baker Tool TOTCO Recorder shall be used during the drilling to ensure that the hole is not drifting from vertical.  
When total depth of the borehole is reached at the proper diameter, circulation shall be maintained for approximately one (1) hour to assure that the hole is free of cuttings and cavings.

total length of the borehole casing shall be made up of sections of any standard length, but minimum length of sections should be 3 m. Casing string must be made of the same type 
(diameter, wall thickness, and composition) of casing section for its total depth.  
Before proceeding with drilling the contractor must notify the Commission in writing with dimensions of the chosen casing. Threaded casing joints using BTC (buttress -threaded 
connections) are preferred. All threaded joints should be coated with joint compound and 
tightened using sufficient torque.  A torque of 1000 foot -pounds is recommended.  Any casing 
that meets these specifications is acceptable.

3.3.4 Cementation and grouting  
The Contractor has the flexibility of selecting a preferred cementation method that will completely bond the casing string to the rock walls over its entire depth with no voids or shrinkage. For example, cementation can be accomplished through the casing using a cement shoe and plunger method, cementation can be done via external grout tubes in the annulus between the casing and host rock where the casing string is sealed by a welded plate at the 
bottom. However, the preferred cementation process is to pump  cement grout through the 
interior of the casing using a plunger and cement shoe and flush the full volume up the annular 
space between the exterior casing wall and the rock to the surface. The cement shoe and collar 8 
 will form the cement plug at the bottom of the casing. Typical cement grout composition uses 
cement, sand, bentonite (clay), water, and an expansive additive to prevent shrinkage upon drying.  
The borehole shall be cemented from bottom to top. The following procedure is recommended.  Cement slurry with sufficient volume to fill the annulus with at least 25% excess shall be 
pumped into the casing. Then a latch down plug shall be inserted into the casing and washed 
down with clear water.  When the plug reaches the baffle, normally 1,000 pounds per square 
inch of pressure should force the latching nose of the plug into the baffle and lock it in place.  Once the plug is seated, all pressure must be released to check for zero back -flow, this will 
prove that the one -way valves are holding. When zero back- flow is obtained, the cement slurry 
shall be allowed to cure for 24 hours under no pressure before performing any activities that could disturb the bond, such as blowing or bailing the borehole dry of water or proceeding with the acceptance tests.   
After 24 hours, the casing shall be scraped, brushed, and emptied of all fluids and loose solids.  If the cement level drops in the annular space between the pipe and the hole, additional cement 
slurry may be added around the casing directly from the surface.  The level of the cement grout 
in the annular space between the casing and the rock wall must be monitored during the hardening process.  If the level drops, additional cement grout must be added around the casing from the top using small feed pipes if necessary.

 7. ANNEX: Technical Report for the cleaning of the existing Borehole 
 
As part of the BBTS station restoration project, the HYDROCONSULTANCE company cleaned the well in order 
to make it dry for the proper functioning of the seismic probe.  
 
7.1 Resources used during the cleaning.  
A 7.5KW power submersible pump with an electrical box.  
A 25KVA generator.  
A HDPE drainage tube with a diameter of 50mm and a length of 80m with accessories.  
An electrical cable with a diameter of 4X6mm and a length of 100m. 
A rope with a diameter of 15mm.  
A double cabin pickup.  
 
7.2 Works performed.  
The drilling cleaning work took place from 11/17/2023 to 11/18/2023.  
11/17/2023:  
- Installation of equipment on site  
- Connection of the pump with the columns, the group generator and electric cable  
- Lowering the pump to a depth of 55 m  
- Progress of cleaning the well by pumping. 
11/18/2023  
- Installation of the pump to the bottom approximately 60m  
- Continued pumping until reaching the bottom of the borehole. 
- Demobilization of equipment  
7.3 Results  
-  Before pumping the water level in the well (static level) was 14.30m, after 05 minutes of 
pumping the level dropped to 49.50m compared to the ground for the first day  
-  On the second day (11/18/2023) the water level rose slightly by a few centimeters to 49.30m  
When the pump descended to the bottom of the well and after pumping for 2 minutes, the level 
dropped to 59.60m. The color of the water was blackish, of poor quality which can be explained by very slow recharge and a slight deterioration of the walls of the borehole.  
 
7.4 Conclusions and recommendations  
Due to the low rise in the water level, the borehole is still functional and can house the seismic probe. We recommend cementing the bottom of the well to avoid water recharge in the borehole.
